note.p: James Whitfield was a politician in Mississippi, who served in the state legislature and as governor.

Born on December 15, 1791, in Elbert County, Georgia, he moved to Columbus, Mississippi, as a young man. He gained significant wealth as a businessman and planter, and became active in state politics in the 1840s. He won a seat in the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1842 and served in that body until being elected to the Mississippi Senate around 1850.

In 1851, the Mississippi Supreme Court passed a ruling that declared all state officers held limited terms that expired at the general election. The decision caused several vacancies, including in the governor’s office. The state senate convened and elected Whitfield as president on the twenty-first ballot in late November 1851, which placed him in line to fill the vacant gubernatorial seat. He immediately became acting governor and held that position until governor-elect Henry Foote was formally inaugurated on January 10, 1852.

Whitfield temporarily stepped away from politics opened an insurance company and bank in 1852 that remained profitable for nearly two decades. He donated 185 acres in northern Mississippi for the construction of the Mississippi State Hospital. In 1858, he was again elected to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served until 1862. He stepped away from his political and business work in 1870. Whitfield died on June 25, 1875, in Columbus. He was married to Caroline H. Dyer and had at least eight children. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; National Governors Association; David Sansing, “James Whitfield: Eighteenth Governor of Mississippi: November 1851-January1852,” Mississippi History Now)

note.p: Benjamin Grubb Humphreys was governor of Mississippi from 1865 to 1868, during the first three years of Reconstruction. Born on August 26, 1808, in Claiborne County, Mississippi, Humphreys spent many years in the north as a boy, attending school in New Jersey and then being appointed to the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York. Enrolled in the same class as Robert E. Lee, Humphreys was expelled shortly afterwards for his participation in the “Eggnog riot” (or “grog mutiny”)—an alcohol-fueled ruckus at West Point on the night of December 24-25, 1826, that resulted in the removal of twenty students.

Humphreys returned to Mississippi where he studied law and helped his father on the family plantation. He married Mary McLaughlin in 1832. The couple had two children before Mary died in 1835. He remarried in 1839 to Mildred Maury and had at least ten more children.

In the 1830s, Humphreys entered local politics as a Whig, serving as a state representative and then as a member of the Mississippi senate from 1839 to 1844. He purchased land to establish a cotton plantation in Sunflower County, Mississippi, in 1846, and helped establish the town of Itta Bena.

During the lead up to the Civil War, Humphreys opposed secession. However, after Mississippi declared its separation from the Union and joined the Confederate States of America, he volunteered for military service and was eventually elected colonel of the Twenty-first Mississippi Infantry. Humphreys and his regiment served within Brigadier General William Barksdale’s brigade in the eastern theater, notably seeing action at the Peach Orchard during the Battle of Gettysburg on July 2, 1863. Barksdale was killed during the battle, and Humphreys was promoted to brigadier general to take his place. He remained in command of the brigade until September 1864 when he was wounded at Berryville, Virginia. He spent the rest of the Civil War recuperating from his wounds.

Humphreys became active in the immediate postwar political scene in Mississippi. He won election for governor in October 1865 during Mississippi’s effort to earn readmission into the Union under President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction plan. However, Humphreys was among the former southern leaders initially denied presidential pardon by Johnson. Although Johnson soon relented, sending a pardon to Humphreys, the Mississippi legislature’s passage of highly discriminatory laws (known as the Black Codes) against recently emancipated African Americans sparked a fierce backlash by Republicans in the United States Congress, who then refused to admit Mississippi back into the Union. Federal authorities instituted a stricter Reconstruction program, which included oversight by military officials. Humphreys remained governor, as Reconstruction did not disassemble Mississippi’s civil government. However, Humphreys did not enjoy the full authority of a traditional state executive. His white supremacist views and opposition to Black civil rights put him in frequent opposition to Republican Reconstruction goals. He won reelection in 1868, but soon afterwards was ejected from office by federal authorities when Radical Republicans took more direct control of Reconstruction.

Following his removal as governor in 1868, Humphreys left politics and began working in insurance in Jackson, Mississippi. He retired in 1877 and died in December 1882 and is buried in Wintergreen Cemetery at Port Gibson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Benjamin Grubb Humphreys: Twenty-sixth Governor of Mississippi: 1865–1868,” Mississippi History Now; “Benjamin Grubb Humphreys,” HarpWeek)

gloss.p: Cotton is a native plant to the Americas which produces puffy bolls of soft white fibers used for clothing and fabric production since the prehistoric era. There are two main species of cotton—distinguished primarily by their fiber length. Short staple cotton has shorter fibers but can grow across a broader geographical area in the southern United States. Long staple cotton is considered by many to produce higher quality, softer fibers, but is more tropical and frost sensitive, isolating it to the warm coastal areas of the lower south.

Long staple cotton became a highly prized cash crop for seventeenth and eighteenth century farmers in the lower south, particularly along the South Carolina and Georgia coastline. Sea Island cotton was carefully cultivated and developed by planters who imported long fiber plants from Central and South America to improve the quality. This lucrative crop was labor intensive, requiring laborers to pick the bolls by hand—a task increasingly given to enslaved people. Once collected, the cotton bolls had to be processed to remove seeds so the fibers could be spun into thread and the seeds used for planting or for cottonseed oil production. Early American cotton planters used a simple cotton gin (or cotton engine), originally designed in India in the fifth century, to mechanically separate seeds from the long staple fibers. This basic gin did not work with short fiber cotton. Because of this, short staple cotton was not a popular crop during the colonial era, as the manual labor required to separate seeds from the bolls was time and cost prohibitive.

This changed in the 1790s when inventor Eli Whitney designed a new cotton gin that could efficiently separate seeds from short staple cotton. The design immediately made the heartier short fiber cotton plant a viable cash crop and spurred the expansion of cotton farming—on large plantations to small farms—across the south. The pursuit of new farmland for cotton production drove westward migration, the displacement of Native Americans in the south, and helped the creation of new states, including Alabama and Mississippi. The cotton gin only mechanized the processing of cotton. Harvesting the cotton bolls was still done by hand (machine harvesting would not become prevalent until the twentieth century). Therefore, the expansion of cotton farms across the south brought with it the rapid growth of slavery.

Planters produced 750,000 bales of cotton in 1830. Twenty years later, in 1850, the south produced 2.85 million bales annually. In 1860, American planters delivered 5.3 million bales. At 400 pounds per bale, the United States produced more than two billion pounds of cotton in 1860. The crop dominated southern agriculture and made the United States one of the world’s top exporters of the product, chiefly to textile mills in England and France. At the eve of the Civil War, southern politicians believed the importance of the south’s cotton exports gave it diplomatic leverage over European powers. Senator James Hammond of South Carolina famously quipped that “no power on earth dares to make war upon [cotton]. Cotton is king.”

Southern secessionist ideas of cotton’s diplomatic influence during the Civil War proved misplaced. The decrease of cotton exports, due to the Union naval blockade and even efforts by Confederate politicians to create international demand by burning 2.5 million bales of southern cotton, failed to coerce England or France to formally side with the Confederacy or make war upon the Union. Strong cotton crops in the 1850s had led to a surplus of cotton in Europe, and Great Britain chose to find alternate sources of cotton (such as India and Egypt) rather than engage embroil itself in the American Civil War. Some desperate southern farmers even traded with federal officials, and occupying Union forces confiscated cotton crops and transferred them north to textile manufacturers in the northeast.

After the Civil War, cotton production remained an important agricultural interest for the south. The abolition of slavery did not end the role African Americans played as the primary source of labor for cotton harvesting. Freed peoples grew their own cotton crops as tenant farmers or sharecroppers across the south through the late nineteenth century, resulting in the south continually exporting millions of bales each year. Although a lucrative crop, the cotton farmers—white and black—rarely enjoyed wealth from their labor, due to periodic market crashes and competition. Cotton farming did not substantially change until the early twentieth century with the advent of mechanized cotton harvesters. (Wikipedia; census.gov; Eugene R. Dattel, “Cotton and the Civil War,” Mississippi History Now; “Cotton Sector at a Glance,” Economic Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture)

Plantations are farms that typically grow cash crops, and often specialize in a single product, such as cotton, tobacco, or sugar cane. Plantation farming continues in various parts of the world in the twenty-first century, especially for crops like coffee beans, rubber trees, and cocoa. In American history the term plantation is most often associated with estates in the American south. Historical descriptions of plantations generate images of large farming operations. However, even moderately-sized southern farms that planted cash crops were sometimes referred to as plantations.

Southern plantations before the Civil War were strongly tied to the institution of slavery. As profit-driven agricultural operations, plantations required large numbers of laborers. This fed the demand for African slave importation to the British colonies in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and bolstered the defense of slavery among southern planters in the nineteenth century. Plantation crops varied by region within the south, with rice being popular in Georgia and South Carolina along the Atlantic coast, tobacco being an early cash crop in Virginia, and then—after the invention of the cotton gin at the end of the eighteenth century which quickly separated seeds from the cotton fibers—the boom in cotton growing across the Deep South.

By 1860, there were approximately 46,200 plantations across the south. More than 20,000 had twenty to thirty slaves. Only about 2,300, or five percent, had one hundred or more slaves. The enslaved African Americans carried out most of the farming, construction, and domestic work. The plantations were their home. The same was not always true for the plantation owners. The very large operations frequently had wealthy absentee owners, who resided in cities or other states, leaving plantation supervision responsibilities to hired white overseers. Smaller plantation owners usually lived on their property, but almost always in separate buildings from the enslaved laborers. Slave cabins, or slave quarters, were a ubiquitous part of a plantation. They represented the heart of the laborers’ community on the property, but were usually of basic construction and few amenities.

Following the abolition of slavery after the Civil War, many freed people continued to live on plantations. Sharecropping became a popular arrangement between the landowners and the laborers. The property was often divided into plots with tenants assigned to certain sections. The system involved a contract or arrangement which allowed the laborer, or tenant, to keep a portion of the crop they raised. The system was abused, and developed a negative reputation for the level of poverty many sharecroppers (mostly Black, but some white) experienced on plantations in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Representatives of the Freedmen’s Bureau sought to protect Black sharecroppers by regulating contracts during Reconstruction, but the withdrawal of federal officials after 1876 left many African American tenants more subject to unfair sharecropping contracts on the old plantations. (Wikipedia)

Plantation crops varied by region within the south, with rice in Georgia and South Carolina along the Atlantic coast, tobacco being an early cash crop in Virginia, sugar cane in Louisiana, and cotton across the Deep South.

By the mid-nineteenth century, Mississippi was the top cotton producing state in the Union. In 1860, it had around 37,000 farms. Almost 25,000 of them were plantations over one hundred acres in size, although only 481 were truly extravagant at over one thousand acres. Cotton production required farmers and planters to invest a great deal into labor and equipment, leading Mississippi to rank third among the slaveholding states for total value of farm machinery ($8.8 million in 1860, or $330 million today), slightly trailing Virginia ($9.4 million in 1860, or $355 million today) and well behind Louisiana ($18.6 million in 1860, or $702 million today).

Although plantations were profit-driven operations, many in Mississippi were self-sufficient, with subsistence farm plots and livestock to feed the labor force. Enslaved African Americans carried out most of the farming, construction, and domestic work on plantations. The plantations were their home. The largest plantations were like small villages, with many different buildings, including the master’s house (usually large and extravagant), barns, workshops, storage facilities, and slave quarters. Some plantation owners lived part-time on the property, or visited only occasionally, residing most of the year in cities or other states. They left plantation supervision responsibilities to hired white overseers. Smaller plantation owners usually lived on their property, but almost always in separate buildings from the enslaved laborers.

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

The United States Constitution was ratified in 1788 as the foundational code of laws for the United States of America. It was crafted in 1787 by a convention in Philadelphia originally tasked only with amending the existing Articles of Confederation, which had loosely combined the states under a weak central government. Delegates chose to set aside the articles entirely and create a stronger federal government made of three branches: the legislative (comprising two separate parts, the House of Representatives and the Senate), the judicial (led by the Supreme Court), and the executive (headed by the President of the United States). The Constitution sought to carefully balance competing interests regarding state and national authority, as well as large and small state representation. It also created a more direct relationship between Americans and the national government.

The convention’s departure from its original mandate to amend the Articles of Confederation generated controversy, particularly among Americans who opposed placing a distant central authority of the states. The Constitution’s supporters advocated the need for a stronger national government and explained that the federal system preserved state authority for most local matters. To guarantee enough support for ratification, the Constitution’s supporters agreed to add an addendum to more directly protect individuals' specific rights and freedoms. The Constitution was ratified in 1788 and the new United States government began in early 1789. Shortly afterwards, the new Congress adopted several amendments to the Constitution, ten of which were ratified by three-fourths of the states and became known as the Bill of Rights. These first ten amendments guaranteed certain rights for American citizens. Since then, seventeen additional amendments have been ratified to the United States Constitution. Three of them—the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments—were adopted between 1865 and 1870, during the Reconstruction Era. The Thirteenth Amendment formally abolished slavery. The Fourteenth Amendment provides equal protection for all laws and the Fifteenth Amendment protects voting rights for American citizens regardless of “race, color, or previous condition of servitude,” both specifically to combat racial discrimination against African Americans following the end of slavery. (Wikipedia; National Archives and Records Administration)

Ratified in 1865, the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution formally abolished slavery. It was the first of three amendments ratified during Reconstruction in the wake of the Civil War.

The amendment’s origins are largely tied to the United States government’s shift against the institution of slavery following President Abraham Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War. Enacted on January 1, 1863, the proclamation had declared all slaves in Confederate-controlled areas permanently free. (Though not recognized by the Confederate government, the proclamation ensured that all slaves who fled Confederate masters for federal lines or were liberated by Union armies were freed without their former masters being compensated.) The proclamation had not freed enslaved people held in loyal Union states (such as Missouri, Kentucky, Maryland, and Delaware), or Union-controlled parts of the deep South. It had been a military measure issued by Lincoln as commander in chief and had standing only in areas actively in rebellion at the time of its signing. Despite its limitations, the Emancipation Proclamation had signaled the ultimate extinction of slavery within the Union, sparking policy and legislative efforts to abolish the institution across the country—including what became the Thirteenth Amendment. Lincoln lobbied various state and federal representatives for abolition, in part due to fear that his Emancipation Proclamation might be overturned by courts following the war.

In 1863 and 1864, Republican senators and congressmen made various proposals for a constitutional amendment to abolish slavery. One version passed the U.S. Senate in April 1864, but failed to garner the necessary two-thirds votes in the House of Representatives. Opponents of the amendment in Congress did not defend slavery along moral lines, but expressed concern of excessive federal authority. Other critics voiced fears that the abolition of slavery would lead to African American citizenship.

Lincoln’s platform for the 1864 presidential election contained a promise to abolish slavery by constitutional amendment. His reelection victory energized Republicans, and in December 1864 he lobbied Congress to move forward with the amendment as soon as possible. Over the next few weeks, Republican officials labored tirelessly to rally enough votes in Congress to pass the amendment previously approved by the Senate. On January 13, 1865, with unanimous support among Republicans and Unconditional Unionists, and fourteen Democrats (most of whom were “lame duck” members of Congress who had already lost reelection), the House of Representatives narrowly passed the Thirteenth Amendment. Its text read: “Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.” A second section of the amendment affirmed that Congress had full authority to enforce the amendment through legislation.

Upon passage by Congress, the Thirteenth Amendment needed ratification by 27 of 36 states. Twenty-one states had ratified it when Lincoln was assassinated in April 1865. Vice President Andrew Johnson assumed the role of president and took lead in Reconstruction policies. Unionist governments in some former Confederate states had ratified the amendment quickly, including Louisiana and Virginia. Others pushed back due to concerns of the status of freed people afterwards; many southern politicians voiced fears that Republicans would use the amendment to force states to allow African Americans to vote. Johnson assured southern leaders that state governments could handle most social and political matters within their populations after abolition. Over the course of several months, additional states ratified the amendment. On December 6, 1865, Georgia became the twenty-seventh state to ratify, allowing the amendment to go into effect.

The Thirteenth Amendment was a landmark act in the United States, formally ending the institution of slavery. However, it did not prohibit racial discrimination or protect the civil rights of freed people. Additionally, many southern states found alternate ways to bypass the Thirteenth Amendment for forced labor, including peonage laws, which forced African Americans in debt into oppressive labor contracts, and criminal convictions for small actions that technically met the amendment’s exception for involuntary servitude as a punishment of a crime. Mississippi was among the leading states to counteract the advancement of Black southerners in the wake of the Thirteenth Amendment, passing a series of policies known as the “Black Codes,” some of which punished African Americans with forced labor on plantations for petty crimes. As a result, Republicans proposed additional amendments and laws to better ensure the rights and privileges of Americans regardless of color. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi judiciary was established by Article 6 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890. It is one of three branches of the Mississippi state government, along with the executive branch and the legislative branch. The judiciary branch is composed of four tiers of court: limited jurisdiction, general jurisdiction, intermediate appellate, and last resort. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi High Court of Errors and Appeals was created by the 1832 state constitution and was comprised of three popularly-elected justices. It remained the highest appellate court in the state until 1869, when it was replaced by the state Supreme Court. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: In the nineteenth century, across the United States, women’s opportunities were limited. The vestiges of an element of English common law called coverture ensured women did not have a legal identity. Their fathers covered them until they married, at which point they fell under the legal identity of their husbands. In practice, this meant that women did not legally own property and did not even control their own children. They could not own businesses and could not bring suit to court. Rather, they had to rely on a husband, father, or other male relative. The concept of “Republican Motherhood,” however, ensured that some education was necessary. This ideal, which emerged after the American Revolution, held that mothers were central to raising virtuous boys who would one day shape the Republic.

In the North, the Second Great Awakening and the rise of the middle class expanded women’s opportunities further. Heavily centered around the family, the middle class celebrated not an authoritative father but a loving mother. Separate spheres ideology held that men and women occupied different elements of society. Men were responsible for the public sphere, including politics and work outside of the home. Women took care of the domestic sphere, pushing temperance, self-control, hard work, honesty, and frugality. They had considerable power within this space, including nurturing children. Embracing these domestic ideals also pushed northern women into the public domain through such crusades as temperance and moral reform.

In the agrarian South, patriarchy reigned supreme, where a male patriarchal “master” headed a family of dependents – women, children, and enslaved people, when financially possible. Here, men were virtually the law within the household. This hierarchy – and the dependent role women maintained – played a crucial role in uniting the South in its defense of slavery, for all white men were essentially “masters.” Operating with very little personal freedom, elite white women in the South also played a central role in managing the plantation household, overseeing large staffs of enslaved men and women within the domestic sphere. This expectation included embracing the violence that was necessary to maintaining the institution of slavery. Completely dependent on a male patriarch, women working outside of the home were limited to the occupations of the domestic realm, including working as a seamstress or milliner, teaching, domestic service, and sex work. Significantly lower paid than their male counterparts, these limitations ensured that poor white women often carried the burden of poverty in the South.

The institution of slavery ensured that Black women faced still more limited circumstances. As chattel, they were defined by their productive capacity – their ability to produce in the field, the enslaver’s household, or reproductively. Subject to violence, rape, and the inability to control even their own children, enslaved women found ways to carve out elements of independency. Although enslavers sometimes forced enslaved men and women to engage in marital unions with spouses of the enslaver’s choosing, Black women often selected their own husbands, resisting the fact that these unions were only rarely enshrined in law and were subordinate to an enslaver’s desires. As far as was possible, these marriages followed the gendered division of labor typical throughout the U.S., where women were responsible for cooking, cleaning, and caring for children. Within these private households and the slave quarters more generally, enslaved women also engaged in the religions and cultural practices of their ancestry, including Caribbean and African influences.

The Civil War expanded women’s roles in society. Still within the realm of the domestic sphere, women in both regions formed Ladies Military Aid Societies, with an eye towards supporting soldiers. These groups sent domestic necessities, including clothing, socks, and bandages, and they eventually embraced nursing. In the South, societies even began making cartridges and preparing sandbags. Such work and the broader need for women to maintain the household without a male counterpart ensured that women took on new responsibilities, many of which pushed them deeper into the public sphere than was possible before the war. In the South, poor women even became active in demanding that the Confederacy support their families, even rioting publicly in places like Richmond. As many Black women escaped to the U.S. Army during the war, marriage often became their first goal, even forcing the federal government to implement new policies that protected and supported their families. They seized this opportunity to rebuild the families that had long-been severed by the institution of slavery.

After the war, many of these expansions in women’s roles declined, but they did not disappear entirely. Northern women became active in providing support for veterans and their families, even helping navigating the pension system, while southern white women became active in burying the dead, memorialization, and the emergence of the Lost Cause mythology. This idea downplayed the role of slavery in the war and celebrated the Confederacy for its protection of families, within which, women were vital. Black women continued to lobby the U.S. government, including utilizing the Freedman’s Bureau to relocate members of their families and to solidify those unions. With intimate knowledge of the skills and length of individual tasks, they also played pivotal roles in negotiating the financial value of their labor and of negotiating the terms of free labor more generally. Nevertheless, the sexual victimization of Black women continued, becoming a prominent feature of the postwar South.

(Linda K. Kerber, Women of the Republic: Intellect & Ideology in Revolutionary America; Christine Stansell, City of Women: Sex and Class in New York 1780-1860; Mary P. Ryan, Cradle of the Middle Class: The Family in Oneida County, New York, 1790-1865; Stephanie McCurry, Masters of Small Worlds: Yeoman Households, Gender Relations, and the Political Culture of the Antebellum South Carolina Low Country; Elizabeth Fox-Genovese, Within the Plantation Household: Black and White Women of the Old South; Ruth Poe White, “Orphans, White Unity, and the Charleston Orphan House, 1860-1870; Tera W. gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 3–4, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that “free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts.” (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 224–25, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

div.p:
Plantation, near Artesia, Lowndes Co.,
Missi., May 1st 1866.

His Excellency B. G. Humphreys,
Governor &c
Jackson, Missi.
Dear Sir:

I desire to call your attention to some proceedings which have been instituted under an act of the Legislature, of which I was ignorant until a few days sinceand the execution of which, I learn, has been suspended by proclamation of your Excellency.

A few months since I purchased six ordinary shot guns and two or three pistols,which I placed in the hands of my most trusty freedman for the purpose of protecting my horse, cats, hogs, cattle &c from depredation, as also, for use in guarding my grist mill and cotton factory at night, which I have recently erected on my place, and about which I constantly keep from two to four watchmen during the night. There were also two other guns on the plantation, and probably some three pistols, which belonged to the negroes themselves.
My reasons for allowing the negroes to have possession of the fire arms at all were 1st I was satisfied
[seal]
if I did not allow them to have a small number in such way as I could control them they would have them secretly against my will—
Secondly, I really thought such course would be a protection to my property in the present condition of the country.

Thirdly, I was entirely unaware of any law on the subject, had no intention or desire to isolate the law, and never knew there was such an act until a few weeks since. I find scarcely a citizen of the county who knows of the existence of the law, owing to the peculiar circumstances by which we are surrounded, want of communication, mails, newspapers &c at the time the Legislature was in session.

When I allowed the freedmen to have the use of the guns, it was with the distinct understanding that they were to be used in a proper manner; that, they might ocasionally hunt with them on my premises; that there was to be no shooting at unusual times; and that, wherever they used them in an improper manner, or there was any reasonable complaint, the arms were to be at once taken away from them. There was a time or two some shooting at night, which was promptly checked and once on the Sabbath, for which the man was arraigned and fined by the Magistrate of the beat. There had been some shooting in the neighborhood on sabbath, which was laid upon the freedmen on my place, but which on investigation was proved to have been done repeatedly
by the freedman on a neighboring plantation.

It seems that several of my neighbors objected to the negroes having guns, but without mentioning the matter to me, reported it to the magistrate of the beat. On the 12th of April he summoned me to appear before him on the 16th of the same month to answer for the offence. On the 14th of April he sent an armed posse to my plantation under charge of the constable with a paper of which the following is a copy—

"The State of Mississippi
Lowndes County

"To any lawful officer of said
County— Greeting—"

"You are hereby commanded without delay to go to H.B. Whitfields's plantation, Alexander Lido's plantation, and procure and bring to me all the fire arms and ammunition to be found on said plantations, and also to take from any and all freedmen any arms or ammunition found in their possession, and also to arrest all freedmen so found with arms or ammuition, and bring them before me to be dealt with according to law".

"Given under my hand and seal of office
14th of April 1866."

(signed) Theo. Harvey [seal]
"Justice of the Peace"—
There was no affidavit made before the Magis-
trate charging any offence against me, or any against the freedman on my place, or giving any description of the place, person or things to be searched or seized, nothing but the above vague warrant.

When the posse came to my plantation on Saturday afternoon, April 14th the negroes were at work in the field, and seeing so many men on horses, and knowing I had been summoned to answer for their having the arms in possession, they came toward the house in a great hurry. The plough hands who were on mules were ahead, were stopped at a gate before reaching the house by a part of the posse, pistols drawn on them threats made &c &c. Not one of the negroes offered the slightest resistance or used a single impertinent word. In fact, during the whole time the posse was engaged in searching the houses, there was but a single instance of any thing approaching impertinence and that I checked immediately.

At first, I objected to the entire proceeding, search &c, said the paper was not sufficient warrant of authority for the act, and told the party they could do as they pleased at their risk of the consequence. Upon reflection, however, and at the suggestion of the constable who I believe was disposed to act in a gentlemanly manner, and in order to avoid any appearance of difficulty or resistance, I directed all the freedmen who had any arms of mine in their possession, or any of their own, to bring up to me, which they did

without hesitation, with two exceptions, and these two men were absent from the place. The arms were delivered to the constable with the understanding that they were to be delivered to the magistrate to abide the further action in the case. After this, many of the posse insisted upon searching the houses, chests &c of the freedmen anyway, and wished my permission to do so. I did not give my consent, but told them I did not wish them to break any of the people's locks, boxes or chests and that as they were determined to make the search, rather than have them break any thing I would have the negroes to unlock their doors, or boxes, at least those of them that were locked, some of the freedmen and women being still in the field. The search was made thoroughly, in many cases all the negroes clothing thrown upon the floor, their bedding overhauled, trampled upon &c. There was found in all a little more than a pound of powder, three or four pounds of shots, and three or four boxes of caps, all of which were taken and carried away by the posse. Before they left, I called attention again to the informality of the papers, and that I had not waived any legal rights in the transaction. There are a few more than one hundred men and women on any plantation, from which you will perceive there was no great likelihood of a serious disturbance, or any at all, from the quantity of fire arms and ammunition on the place. The negroes were considerably alarmed

and much disturbed about the matter, and wanted to go almost en masse to the freedmen vs bureau at Columbus; but I told them to select four of the most intelligent and I would go with them in person before the commissioner to see that the case was impartially represented. The commissioner, Maj. Smith, took a very conservative view of the case, thought that it was best, as a general thing, for the freedmen not to have arms, but thought the people had been very badly treated in this instance; and gave them some good advice as to their general conduct and legal rights. He is of opinion, that, the law can not be enforced, or will not be allowed to be enforced by the United States government. He also informed me, that, the execution of this law had been suspended by proclamation of your excellency; and the county attorney of the county court, gave me the same information; but neither of them had a copy of the proclamation.

On the 16th of April I appeared before the Magistrate, and carried with me all the men who had any arms in their possession. This officer had no certifed or duly printed or published copy of the law; and I also stated to him what I had learned as to the suspension of the law. But, he said, he could not recognize the authority or power of the Governor to suspend an act of the Legislature. So, seeing he was determined to bind all hands over for appearance at the County Court, at Columbus, on the 2nd
Monday in May, and knowing he had no right to make a final decision in the case, I entered into bond for the appearance of the freedmen and myself at the ensuing term of the County Court.

I also have a plantation just on the edge of Noxubee county on this place I have some forty odd freedmen and women, and had two (2) guns in possession of the freedmen, which were my property. Two of them had also had a pistol each, their own property, which they had sold some two months since. All of the men and boys on this place were summarily arrested and carried under guard before the magistrate of the beat, and the two men who had permission to use the two guns so long as they did so in a proper manner and those who had sold the pistols were committed to jail. They were released upon my giving bond for their appearance at Court. I would state here, that these men as also those on my place here, had my express consent to use the arms so long as they did so in a proper manner, and could not have thad them without. They had no intention to violate the law, for like myself they were not aware of its existence. Though, technically ignorance of the law is no excuse. Upon appearance at the County Court, at Macon, the freedmen were fined five ($5) dollars each and I was fined the same for allowing them to have the guns. The fines and entire costs of suit will amount to quite one hundred dollars which rather than open the many vexatious questions

that would arise in a higher Court, the delay and trouble of investigation &c. I have thought it best to pay, though I feel sure the whole proceeding is wrongful from the beginning, and instigated more from malice towards the freedmen and myself than any desire to promote the interest of the community.

My object in calling your attention to this matter, and going so much into detail is, to ask your suggestions and advice in the matter; as also, an official copy of your proclamation suspending this law, if such has been issued as I am informed,feeling sure you may hear of these particular cases from another quarter.

I desire also to assure you, that , it was no part of my intention to violate any law when I allowed these freedmen to have the arms, for I was not aware of its existence. I believe also, that the law is in conflict with the letter and spirit of the amendment to our state constitution, as also, the amendment to the constitution of the United States, abolishing slavery, guaranteeing rights of person, property &c and I am sure, that portion of it is, which declares all arms found in possession of the freedmen to be forfeited to the informer. And further, there is no doubt in my mind, that the enforcement of such laws will not be permitted by the United States government, no matter what the courts may decide as to the constitutionality of the "Civil Rights Bill". It seems to me the best

course for us to pursue now in all such cases will be to regulate matters of this character by contracts with the freedmen. This will reach the case effectually, if justified by public opinion. The law on the subject is not enforced in scarcely any neighborhood in the state; not at all in the large towns, so far as I have been able to learn. The freedmen in almost every plantation in this action and in the town, have guns and pistols in possession. Many of the merchants sell them and ammunition and whiskey, not knowing the existence of the law in question.

If you desire to have any reference as to my character standing &c I refer to Maj. L. Divers, or Maj Thos. C. Fearns of Jackson; and also state that I am a son of Ex-Gov. Jas. Whitfield of Columbus, with whom you may be acquainted; and that, I have been a resident of this county from early youth, having resided in Columbus since the first part of the year 1839.
If possible, please let me hear from you by communication directed to me at Columbus, Mississippi, in order to reach me before the 2nd Monday in May.

Very Respectfully
Your Obt. Servt.
[seal]
May 4th 1866

Artesia, Lowndes Co.
Miss. May 1st 1866.
Whitfield—Henry B.
Letter of—

Calling attention to some proceedings which have been instituted under an act of the Legislature, the execution of which he understands had been suspended by proclamation of the Execution; The Act referred to- that in relation to disarmament of negroes
